body_html:
Thanks for the quick response @tatatodd

Can you expand a bit on what problem you're actually trying to solve? Or were you just playing around with things?

I am implementing an RNN which, at time t, may need to access not just the output at t-1 but also outputs from earlier time steps. That's why I'd like to pass around a TensorArray and update it as I go along. In #2237 there are several examples of RNNs of this kind, such as this simple Tree-RNN by @lukasr0.

I can emulate a scan by using tf.while_loop instead, like in the linked Tree-RNN example, but it's a bit cumbersome and it doesn't seem to be very efficient.

I am implementing an RNN which, at time t, may need to access not just the output at t-1 but also outputs from earlier time steps. That's why I'd like to pass around a TensorArray and update it as I go along. In #2237 there are several examples of RNNs of this kind, such as this simple Tree-RNN by @lukasr0.
I can emulate a scan by using tf.while_loop instead, like in the linked Tree-RNN example, but it's a bit cumbersome and it doesn't seem to be very efficient.
body:
Thanks for the quick response @tatatodd 

> Can you expand a bit on what problem you're actually trying to solve? Or were you just playing around with things?

I am implementing an RNN which, at time `t`, may need to access not just the output at `t-1` but also outputs from earlier time steps. That's why I'd like to pass around a `TensorArray` and update it as I go along. In #2237 there are several examples of RNNs of this kind, such as [this simple Tree-RNN](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/2237#issuecomment-233439285) by @lukasr0.

I can emulate a scan by using `tf.while_loop` instead, like in the linked Tree-RNN example, but it's a bit cumbersome and it doesn't seem to be very efficient.
